user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
- test_code: a modified OS_NetworkGetID code that contains useful probe functions that print useful logs to a file "/tmp/logs/21.txt". The logs should contain the control path and state information of the violation scenario. If the MISRA C rule is not violated, you can just return an empty string for the test code.
Here are the constraints for the test code:
- DO NOT introduce new violations to demonstrate your scenario.
- The test code MUST be compilable and executable.
- The test code MUST include line breaks.
- The test code MUST preserve the original logic of OS_NetworkGetID as much as possible.
- You MUST NOT define the main function.
- You MUST NOT define macros.
- The test code MUST not contain any mock functions.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_NetworkGetID:
```c
int32 OS_NetworkGetID(void)
{
    int32 IdBuf;

    /* always delegate to low-level API */
    if (OS_NetworkGetID_Impl(&IdBuf) != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        /* return a hardcoded value on failure */
        return -1;
    }

    return IdBuf;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function OS_NetworkGetID:
int32 OS_NetworkGetID_Impl(int32 *IdBuf)
{
    /* gethostid() has no failure modes */
    *IdBuf = gethostid();
    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
...
void *UT_Stub_GetReturnValuePtr(UT_EntryKey_t FuncKey, size_t ReturnSize, const char *TypeName)
{
    UT_StubTableEntry_t *StubPtr;
    void *               ReturnPtr;

    ReturnPtr = NULL;
    StubPtr   = UT_GetStubEntry(FuncKey, UT_ENTRYTYPE_RETURN_BUFFER);

    if (StubPtr == NULL)
    {
        /* This shouldn't happen, it means the stub tried to use a
         * return buffer that does not exist.
         *
         * It is most likely caused by a mismatch/incompatibility between
         * stub and handler.  Aborting now is better than segfaulting later,
         * as the errored call should still be on the stack trace
         */
        UtAssert_Abort("Return buffer invalid");
    }
    else
    {
        ReturnPtr = StubPtr->Data.Buff.BasePtr;

        /*
         * Sanity check on the size and type name.
         *
         * In a generated stub these should always match, but if any patches
         * were done or if a hand-written stub is used, mistakes could be made.
         */
        if (StubPtr->Data.Buff.Position != ReturnSize || strcmp(TypeName, StubPtr->Data.Buff.ContentTypeStr) != 0)
        {
            UtAssert_Failed("Return value mismatch, expected %s(%lu) got %s(%lu)", TypeName, (unsigned long)ReturnSize,
                            StubPtr->Data.Buff.ContentTypeStr, (unsigned long)StubPtr->Data.Buff.Position);
        }
    }

    return ReturnPtr;
}
</additional code>
Judge whether the above OS_NetworkGetID code violates the rule 17.8 or not.
scenario: The function OS_NetworkGetID takes a pointer parameter &IdBuf and passes it to OS_NetworkGetID_Impl, which modifies the content of IdBuf. Since OS_NetworkGetID does not modify the pointer itself, only the object it points to, this is compliant with MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8.
